We have measured the magnetic moment of (l-~to.gBao.t)=C-"u.O,-as a
function of temperature and magnetic field and have found the onset of
superconductivity at a temperature T ~ 3,5 K. From the magnetic field
dependencies, we have shown that the sample is a type-II superconductor
with ~ ~ 11. Specific heat measurements ~ield a finite electronic
specific heat coefficient of ~6 mJ/mole-K at 4 K and a Debye
temperature of only 330 K, suggesting that a strong electron-phonon
interaction may be responsible for the high T in our sample.
Recently, high T c La-(Ba,Sr)-Cu-O supercon-
ductors have been intensively investigated, i-a
Bednorz and Muller i have measured the tempera-
ture dependence of the resistivity of
Bao.v6La4.zsCu6Os(3_y) and have found a
superconducting onset temperature Tco = 35 K
followed by the disappearance of resistivity
below To ~ 12 K. C~u et al. 4 have obtained Tco
35 K and To = 14 K for their Lai_xBaxCuOo_y
with x = 0.15 and 0.20, and at a pressure of
12 khar, Tco increases to 52.3 K and To to 25 K.
Very recently, they have improved the quality of
their sample and have obtained an excellent
sample (Lao.4~lao.1)~CuO4_v, whlchhas the K2NiF~
crystal structure with Tc~ = 44 K and To = 28 K,
but, at 10 kber, Tco = q5 and To = 40K.
This
value of To is the highest among the
La-{Ba.Sr)-~--O system. Therefore, it is of
great interest to investigate the magnetic
properties of this material for the purpose of
providing more information on this new type of
high Tcmaterial.
A Quantum Design SQUID susceptometer has
been employed to measure the sample magnetiza-
tion M as a function of applied field and
temperatures. We obtain the susceptibility by K
= d}I/dHH= o. Figure 1 shows our results as a
function of temperature. The susceptibility
becomes negative below To = 31K.
However, it
starts to decrease at Tco = 35 K (not shown).
At 2 K, K = 3.3 x I0 "~ emu/cm 3. which is 42X of
perfect diamagnetism, indicating bulk supercon-
ductivity in the sample.

The magnetization as a function of applied
magnetic field is shown in Figs. 3 and 4 for two
different ranges of applied field. Each of
these M vs. H curves displays a peak, whose
shape is reminiscent of behavior typical for a
type-II superconductor.
From these peaks (Fig.
3), we obtain the lower critical field, H ~.
Its temperature dependence is shown in Fig. 5,
and is quite different from that of a conven-
tional type-If superconductor.
By linearly
extrapolating N at high fields to M = 0 in Fig.
4, we obtain the upper critical field Hc2. Its
temperature dependence is depicted in Fig. 5 and
is again unexpected for a type-If superconduc-
tor. From Hct and Hc=, we can deduce the
coherence length ~ = 6.7 run, the thermodynamic
critical field Hc = 4900 G. and the Ginzburg-
Landau parameter K = 11 at 2 K.

Based on specific heat
measurements on a sample of (Lao.~iSro.og)zCu04
that showed a 55X Meissner effect, a 81) of

If the superconducting fraction of
the sample can be assumed proportional to the
size of the Melssner effect (IOX), then the
nonsuperconducting fraction of approximately 90"Z
must be responsible for the finite ~ value
observed, and the true value of ~ must be at
least lOXhlgher, approximately 6.6 to 7
mJlmole-K ~ . This ~ value is in reasonable
accord wlth that estimated from the Paull
susceptibility (~ = 2.2 mJ/mole-K2). The Debye
temperature is lower than expected, indicating
that the high T c value in our sample may arise
from strong electron-phonon interactions.
In conclusion, mag~etlc measurements have
shown that our sample is a bulk type-II super-
conductor with Tco= 35 K and K = 11. The
value obtained from specific heat is not very
high relatlve to a typical A-15 superconductor
(such as Nb3Sn with ~ = 52 mJ/mole-K2), v We
conclude that a strong electron-phonon inter-
action may be responsible for the high T c.
